channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Coronavirus Live News: Updates and Analysis
item.description: At the hearing, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci told senators that if the country did not adequately prepare, “then we run the risk of having a resurgence.”

item.title: Sentenced for Three Strikes, Then Freed. Now Comes a Pushback.
item.description: Measures that softened California’s sentencing laws are headed for the ballot again.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer
item.media:credit: David Walter Banks for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brian Beinlich is one of an estimated 6,000 inmates sentenced under California’s Three Strikes law who have been freed early or had their sentences reduced since the 1990s-era law was softened in 2012.

item.title: Ahmaud Arbery Case: Georgia Attorney General Appoints Fourth Prosecutor
item.description: Joyette M. Holmes, an Atlanta-area district attorney, will take over a case that has stirred protests, as the Justice Department said it was weighing federal hate crimes charges.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas and Richard Fausset
item.media:description: Demonstrators watched a parade of motorcyclists riding in honor of Ahmaud Arbery in Brunswick, Ga.

item.title: Tribal Nations Face Most Severe Crisis in Decades as the Coronavirus Closes Casinos
item.description: Nearly 500 tribal casinos remain shut down during the pandemic, causing job losses to spike. The economic damage is spreading quickly, wreaking havoc on fragile tribal finances.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Jack Healy
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: The Emerald Queen Casino & Hotel in Tacoma, Wash. The closure of hundreds of tribal casinos in response to the coronavirus outbreak is eviscerating the revenues many Native American nations use to provide basic services.

item.title: When the Campaigns Have Your Digits
item.description: A text from the Trump campaign usually LOOKS LIKE THIS, while Biden texts often go on and on and ….
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti

item.title: Top Science and Health Officials Offer Sobering View of Reopening Readiness
item.description: Despite progress on a vaccine, there is no guarantee it will be effective, experts said, and testing and contact tracing are still short of the levels needed.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas, Denise Grady, Michael Mason and Sheila Kaplan
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions
item.media:description: Dr. Anthony Fauci on Tuesday testified remotely via teleconference before the Senate Committee for Health, Education, Labor and Pensions, in which many of its members also joined remotely.

item.title: Intelligence Chief Declassifies List of Obama-Era Names in Unusual Step
item.description: Richard Grenell has given the list to the Justice Department as the president and his allies press to reshape perception of the Russian investigation.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Katie Benner
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
Office of the Director of National Intelligence
item.media:description: Richard Grenell declassified a list of officials who sought at the end of the Obama administration to understand more about Russia’s communications with Trump associates.

item.title: Aimee Stephens, Transgender Plaintiff in Supreme Court Case, Dies at 59
item.description: Ms. Stephens, who was fired from her job in 2013 after she announced that she would begin living as a woman, won her case in the U.S. Court of Appeals.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz
item.media:credit: Eamon Queeney for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aimee Stephens outside her childhood home in Fayetteville, N.C., in 2018. She was fired from her job in 2013 after she told her colleagues that she would begin living as a woman.

item.title: Ann McBride Norton, First Woman to Run Common Cause, Dies at 75
item.description: In leading a watchdog group, she championed campaign finance reform. John McCain called her “our general and our strategist” in pushing that fight in Congress.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Q. Seelye
item.media:credit: Douglas Graham/Congressional Quarterly, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Ann McBride, the former president of Common Cause, gathered signatures for a grassroots effort to reform campaign finance.

item.title: Richard Fenno, Who Studied Congress Close Up, Dies at 93
item.description: His books broke new ground in political science, emphasizing politicians’ interactions not in Washington but in their home districts.
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger

item.title: Inside Georgia’s Citizen’s Arrest Law: Ahmaud Arbery Case
item.description: From the days of the Civil War, Georgia has allowed its residents to arrest one another. But after the shooting death of Ahmaud Arbery, critics are calling for such laws to be repealed.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:description: Protesters gathered outside the Glynn County Courthouse in Brunswick, Ga., last week after the Georgia Bureau of Investigation arrested a father and son for the killing of Ahmaud Arbery.

item.title: Trailing Women With a Camera Was Legal, Appeals Court Rules
item.description: David Eric Lambert, 40, lurked in stores and followed women around, pointing his phone at their breasts and buttocks, but because he was in public, he committed no crime, an appeals court concluded.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer
item.media:description: David Eric Lambert’s unlawful photography convictions were tossed out last month. “It is simply not reasonable to expect that our fully clothed images will remain totally private,” one of the judges wrote.

item.title: Manhattan Faces a Reckoning if Working From Home Becomes the Norm
item.description: Even after the crisis eases, companies may let workers stay home. That would affect an entire ecosystem, from transit to restaurants to shops. Not to mention the tax base.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Haag
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Companies of all sizes are evaluating their need for office space during the coronavirus pandemic, with potentially profound implications for New York City.

item.title: Democrats Accuse Conservatives of a ‘Dark Money’ Bid to Influence Judges
item.description: A proposal to ban membership among judges in the Federalist Society has set off a partisan battle. The influential group has guided President Trump’s rightward overhaul of the judiciary.
item.dc:creator: Ben Protess and Rebecca R. Ruiz
item.category: American Constitution Society for Law and Policy
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Federalist Society's lawyers convention last year at the Mayflower Hotel in Washington.

item.title: Anti-Semitic Incidents Surged in 2019, Report Says
item.description: The Anti-Defamation League reported more than 2,100 anti-Semitic incidents in the United States, a 12 percent jump and the most in any year since it began tracking them four decades ago.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:description: A show of support outside a home in Monsey, N.Y., where five people were injured in a machete attack during a Hanukkah celebration in December.

item.title: Immigrants on H-1B and Other Work Visas May Face Deportation
item.description: The Trump administration is unlikely to allow laid-off holders of H-1B and other work visas to extend their stay in the country amid the coronavirus pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Andrew Jenkins and Krista York of Minnesota were set to marry on Aug. 22 at the majestic Cathedral of St. Paul. Then the coronavirus struck and Mr. Jenkins, who is British, lost his job as a market research analyst.

item.title: Supreme Court Hears Arguments on Releasing Trump's Tax Returns
item.description: A majority of justices seemed skeptical of an effort by two House committees, but they seemed more sympathetic to the argument of the Manhattan district attorney.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform

item.title: Patagonia, Quick to Close, Could Be Last to Reopen
item.description: It was one of the first retailers to temporarily close as the coronavirus spread. But now, it has lost half of its sales in North America and is looking at a transformed landscape.
item.dc:creator: Sapna Maheshwari
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Keeping their distance at a morning team meeting.

item.title: California and Wisconsin Special Elections: What to Watch For
item.description: In California, the race to fill former Representative Katie Hill’s seat in the state’s 25th District is a microcosm of national politics right now.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina and Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Lauren Justice for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bob and Sharon Zimmerman insert their ballots at the Boys & Girls Club in Wausau, Wis.

item.title: Gov. Newsom's Budget Proposal: Deep Cuts Are Likely
item.description: Tuesday: Jim Newton says the nickname misses the seriousness of Mr. Brown’s spirituality. Also: Election Day in the 25th Congressional District.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan and Conor Dougherty
item.media:description: Members of the Assembly budget committee practiced social distancing during an oversight hearing of the budget special subcommittee on Covid-19 in Sacramento on April 20.

item.title: Biden Says He’s Not ‘Hiding’ at Home, but ‘Winning’ Against Trump
item.description: In an interview on ABC, Joe Biden, the presumptive Democratic nominee, pushed back against concerns from allies that he needs to do more to compete against the highly visible incumbent president.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:description: Mr. Biden has been at home for weeks during the coronavirus pandemic, conducting television interviews from a makeshift studio in his basement.

item.title: As Coronavirus Death Toll in Nursing Homes Climbs, Call to Redesign Them Grow
item.description: Advocates are challenging layouts that are efficient and cost effective but that may allow the coronavirus to spread faster.
item.dc:creator: Jane Margolies
item.media:credit: Jessica Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: At Jewish Senior Services in Bridgeport, Conn., private rooms made a “huge” difference in controlling the coronavirus, the organization’s chief executive said.

item.title: Israeli Soldier Is Killed in West Bank as Tensions Rise Over Annexation Push
item.description: The killing, Israel’s first combat fatality of the year, came amid Palestinian warnings of violent resistance.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers on Tuesday in Yaabed, where a solider was killed while on an arrest mission.

item.title: On Politics: A Warning of ‘Needless Suffering and Death’
item.description: Fauci plans to issue a stark warning on reopening the country: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)

item.title: Coronavirus, Anthony Fauci, California: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt

item.title: ‘It’s Surreal Walking Through the Empty Airports’
item.description: Most business travel has been halted by the coronavirus, but there are some who say they can’t work without flying or at least driving to a job.
item.dc:creator: Julie Weed
item.media:credit: Jenna Schoenefeld for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hollywood Burbank Airport. Airlines have been slashing their flight offerings in the pandemic, especially to smaller airports like Burbank.

item.title: For a City Already in a ‘Death Spiral,’ What’s After Lockdown?
item.description: In Farmington, N.M., the economy was already struggling. Now everyone knows someone who is out of work because of the coronavirus. Very few say they know anyone who got sick.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Casey
item.media:credit: Adria Malcolm for The New York Times
item.media:description: Businesses in Farmington, N.M., have been closed since stay-at-home orders were issued in late March.

item.title: A Rocket Attack. Two Narratives. This Is What Happened.
item.description: Nine Americans were injured last October in an attack by the Taliban in southern Afghanistan. The U.S. military said there were no casualties.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The Marines’ living area on Outpost Bost after a Taliban attack in Helmand Province in October 2019, in a photo leaked with other documents about the attack.

item.title: Reopening Prompts New Agitation Over Workers’ Virus Exposure
item.description: As business restrictions are lifted, employees have moved from advocating workplace safeguards to making sure the measures aren’t removed too soon.
item.dc:creator: Noam Scheiber
item.category: United Food and Commercial Workers Union
item.media:credit: Monica Jorge for The New York Times
item.media:description: Riley Breakell, a Starbucks employee in Farmington, Conn., said she was “very anxious” about going back to work last week.

item.title: ‘These Are Not Numbers, These Are Souls’: Georgia Pastors Say No to Reopening
item.description: Churches in Albany, Ga., have been devastated by the coronavirus. As the state reopens, pastors are uniting to keep people home.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Natalie Reneau

item.title: Momentous Choices for Court as It Hears Trump Financial Records Cases
item.description: The court ruled unanimously against Presidents Richard Nixon and Bill Clinton when they sought to withhold evidence. But the current court is unlikely to achieve consensus.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:description: President Trump has sought to block demands from two House committees and New York prosecutors for his tax returns and other financial information.

item.title: Fauci Plans to Use Hearing to Warn of ‘Needless Suffering and Death’
item.description: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the nation’s top infectious disease expert, is scheduled to testify on Tuesday before the Senate Health Education, Labor and Pensions Committee.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions
item.media:description: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci last month at the White House before a coronavirus task force briefing.

item.title: Stocks Fall Amid Concerns Over Recovery: Live Updates
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:description: Senator Lindsey Graham proposed legislation that would allow sanctions on China.

item.title: Global Coronavirus Tracker: India, Germany, U.K.
item.description: As nations loosen rules, new clusters in places that seemed to have tamed the virus show how hard success is to sustain. In Wuhan, a seemingly small cluster led to a giant response — tests for the entire city.
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: A family heading to board a passenger train to Delhi at the Mumbai central railway station on Tuesday. It was the first such train to depart after India’s train network gradually restarted operations.

item.title: Escaped Peacock Is Lured Back by Mating Call From Police Officer’s Phone
item.description: Snowbank, who will turn 7 in July, may have ventured out from Franklin Park Zoo in Boston in search of love.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:description: Snowbank, a peacock who escaped from the Franklin Park Zoo, was corralled by Boston police officers on Monday.

item.title: California’s Plan to Trace Travelers for Virus Faltered When Overwhelmed, Study Finds
item.description: Identifying and tracing air passengers from high-risk countries is useful when begun early, a C.D.C. study found, but California’s effort came too late.
item.dc:creator: David Waldstein
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Travelers arriving from Asia at Los Angeles International Airport in January.

item.title: Democrats Will Take Their First Step Toward a Virtual Convention
item.description: A vote by the party’s rules committee comes as officials hold out hope for some kind of in-person celebration in August, even as a large gathering appears increasingly unlikely because of the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:description: The Fiserv Forum in Milwaukee is the planned site of this year’s Democratic National Convention.

item.title: Arkansas Professor Is Accused of Hiding Chinese Funding
item.description: The case was the latest example of the Justice Department’s efforts to combat Chinese influence on American campuses.
item.dc:creator: Matt Farwell and Katie Benner
item.media:description: The Justice Department has charged a string of academics with lying about funding from China.

item.title: Indiana Attorney General Suspended by State Supreme Court in Groping Case
item.description: Curtis T. Hill Jr., a Republican, had his law license suspended for 30 days after the court found that he inappropriately touched four women at a party in 2018.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:credit: Robert Franklin/South Bend Tribune, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Curtis Hill, Indiana’s attorney general, in February. He has resisted bipartisan calls to resign.
